Cookbook: Integrating configuration
[Cookbook: Integration issues]

The IPDR transmitter (client) API defines all its configuration values by a name and a MIB OID. There are two mechanisms for configuration:
  • A callback for mapping a name to a value (IPDR_ParametersHandlerFunc, set by IPDR_InitExporter()). For example, you might use this if you do configuration with a Windows-style ".INI" file by simply reading the name=value pairs into a hash table; the callback is just a few lines of code, looking up the name to get the associated value.
  • A MIB value. You could use these if you use SNMP SET on the configuraiton values.

The IPDR_ParametersHandlerFunc is called only when the IPDR transmitter (client) is initialized. If you wish to change a value, you must stop the transmitter and restart it (see Cookbook: Integrating IPDR transmitter (client) start/stop for more on this).

When a MIB value is changed, the transmitter (client) is reconfigured. This may cause the transmitter to briefly disconnect from the collector (server), but does not cause any data loss.

The IPDR_LoadMIBFunc callback is defined in IPDR_InitExporter() and can be used to get initial MIB values from some non-volatile memory.
